entry.title: Re: Has Anyone Integrated GoFluent with SAP SuccessFactor...
entry.content:
Hi @ipadilla ,

ATS / Recruiting integration for assessments

  • goFLUENT offers an ATS integration so assessment assignments and CEFR results can flow back into SuccessFactors Recruiting (candidate record), speeding selection decisions and storing results in the ATS. This is usually done via goFLUENT’s assessment integration/APIs with the Recruiting system.

  • Confirm whether you want Learning OCN, Recruiting ATS assessment, or both.

  • Request goFLUENT integration docs & OCN configuration guide (they have a questionnaire & SSO steps)

  • Provision a SF test instance + goFLUENT sandbox.

  • Exchange SAML metadata & test SSO (Provisioning)

  • Define and test candidate/user ID mappings and test assessment result flow.

  • Validate reporting and data retention / privacy settings.

Reference Link:

  • goFLUENT — Language Assessment + Recruiting/ATS integration info. goFLUENT | United States

  • goFLUENT — Language Training / SuccessFactors Learning (OCN + SAML pages). goFLUENT | United States+1

  • goFLUENT — SSO & API integration pages. goFLUENT | United States+1

  • SAP Knowledge Base — note about provisioning SAML when integrating goFLUENT as OCN provider. SAP Support Portal

Hope this helps!!

Thanks,

kr,

karthick.

Hi @praveen59 ,

There is no additional cost to enable Career Site Builder (CSB) in lower environments (Preview/Stage/TEST) as long as you already have RMK/Recruiting Marketing licensed in Production.

entry.title: Re: Why does SAP always use Periodic Unit Price for valuation when Price Control = V (MAP)?
entry.content:
Hi,

Thank you for the explanation and for sharing the notes related to Periodic Unit Price and costing.

I understand from the documentation that:

  • Periodic price can be activated and used for valuation
  • Moving Average Price logic exists in transaction-based price determination

However, my original concern is not about how Periodic Price works, but rather about the role of Standard Price when Price Control = V.

What is still unclear to me is:

1. Why Standard Price is technically never considered for valuation postings when Price Control = V, even if it is maintained in the material master.

2. Whether this behavior is:

  • A hard-coded SAP design decision, or
  • A result of costing / Material Ledger configuration.

3. From a design perspective, what is the exact purpose of Standard Price under Price Control V:

  • Is it purely informational?
  • Is it only used for comparison, reporting, or planning?

4. Why SAP still allows maintaining Standard Price for materials with Price Control V, if it can never be used as a valuation base in standard transactions.

My intention is to understand the core SAP valuation concept, not only the costing procedure itself. If there is a specific SAP note, help documentation, or design explanation that explicitly states that Standard Price is ignored by design under Price Control V, I would really appreciate the reference.

Thank you in advance for the clarification.

Best regards,
Ester Wang

entry.title: Re: How can I check the subscribed license for SAP Ariba...
entry.content:
To access the license material for SAP Ariba Snap Buying (8008177), follow these steps:

1.Navigate to the Portfolio & Products portal: https://me.sap.com/portfolio
2.Select the My Product Portfolio section via this link: https://me.sap.com/portfolio/portfolioproducts
3.Under the My Purchased Products list, locate SAP Ariba Snap. Click the number displayed in the Materials column next to the product.
4. This action will load the license material details page, where you can view "SAP Ariba Snap Buying (8008177)"

entry.title: euBP in Germany: Generating a Certificate File in Germany’s ITSG Trust Center Portal
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • About ITSG
  • Registration at ITSG Trust Center Portal
  • Step 1 Enter Subscriber Number
  • Step 2 Enter Personal Data of Contact Person
  • Step 3 Confirm Email Address
  • Step 4 Start Identity Verification
  • Step 5 Complete Identity Verification
  • Step 6 Confirm Company Address
  • Step 7 Select Billing Address and Delivery
  • Step 8 Registration as a Collection Center
  • Step 9 Certificate Request Inbound Check
  • Generation of Electronic Keys
  • Submitting the Files to the Trust Center
  • Inbound Check of Certificate Request
  • Step 10 Enter a Tagging Code
  • Transferring Certified Participant Keys and Activation
  • Configuring the Key Data and Certificate File in SAP BTP Cockpit

Note:  The steps and processes described here are accurate as of the time of writing, but it's essential to stay updated with any changes on the ITSG portal that may affect this procedure. Detailed description in German can be found here: https://www.itsg.de/wp-content/uploads/Trust-Center-Registrierungsportal.pdf 

Introduction

In this blog post, I will guide you through the process of generating a certificate file in ITSG Trust Center portal using POSTIDENT. This certificate is essential for establishing a connection between the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (hereafter referred to as the "cloud edition") and the German pension insurance authority's system. This will allow you to submit the required financial accounting data from your business system SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integrated with the cloud edition to the pension insurance authority's system. The requirement is also known as euBP, an abbreviation of the local name Elektronisch unterstützte Betriebsprüfung, or "electronically supported company audit" in English.

About ITSG

ITSG, which stands for Information technology service point of the statutory health insurance GmbH, operates the ITSG Trust Center to create and manage certificates and facilitate secure electronic data exchange in the health and social services sectors. 

Registration at ITSG Trust Center Portal

Access the registration portal of the ITSG Trust Center using the address https://registrierungsportal.itsg.de/regportal/client/de/login . For a new activity, choose the "Register" button and for an existing activity, choose the "Log On" button.

Log on the portal

Step 1 Enter Subscriber Number

First enter the company number, the special sender number or the paying office number for the application as a unique participant number that is to be used in electronic data exchange.

Enter subscriber number

Step 2 Enter Personal Data of Contact Person

The entry of the personal data of the contact person is divided into two areas: contact data and logon data.

Enter contact data

 

 

Enter logon data

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: The first name and last name of the contact person must be entered in full according to the valid German identity card, valid German passport or the official identity cards and passport corresponding to the German identity card. If the name is incomplete or deviates, this leads to a rejection in the registration portal during identity verification after a POSTIDENT procedure.

Step 3 Confirm Email Address

After entering the contact data and logon data, a confirmation e-mail is sent to the specified e-mail address with an activation link for confirmation.

confirmation page

After confirmation, the logon can be performed with the logon data.

Logon after confirmation

Step 4 Start Identity Verification

The contact person must use the registration portal to carry out identification with a POSTIDENT procedure at Deutsche Post AG. The postal identification variant is only possible in Germany. Alternatively, online identification function with online ID function is supported, nut only a German identity card with activated electronic identity (eID) is permitted. 

More information can be found: https://www.deutschepost.de/de/p/postident/privatkunden/faq.html

Identity verification

Step 5 Complete Identity Verification

After the identification has been carried out using a POSTIDENT procedure, the registration portal checks the electronic confirmation from the POSTIDENT system to determine whether the first names and last names entered in step 2 (possibly also double names and titles for last names) match completely and in the sequence specified in the identification documentation. 

Complete identity verification

 After successful identification, you must log on to the registration portal again to continue the further steps. If the identity verification was not completed successfully, you can start a new registration with a new identification using the “Restart Registration” button.

Step 6 Confirm Company Address

The applicant's address is checked against lists of the issuing agencies and must then be confirmed by the contact person. If the displayed address is correct and current, click the “Address is correct” button to proceed to the next step. At the end of the certification, an activation code for activating the security module is sent to the assigned company address of the applicant.


If your company is based outside Germany, you have the option of selecting the country here. As a contact person, you can also enter your name and, for example, manually add department to the displayed address of the applicant.

If the displayed address does not correspond to the actual company address of the applicant, a generated release letter cannot be delivered correctly later in the registration process. In this case, please arrange your adjustment of the company address at the issuing agency for your trading partner number.

Step 7 Select Billing Address and Delivery

By default, your invoice will use the previously confirmed applicant company address from step 6. If the invoice is to be sent to a different billing address, use a different billing address and enter the billing address. 

Use a different billing address

 Enter address

As an alternative, you can choose a delivery by e-mail. To do this, set a checkmark for "Use electronic delivery of invoice" and specify the e-mail address.

Electronic delivery

Step 8 Registration as a Collection Center

Optionally, you can register as a reporting office to transfer notifications for other company numbers in the employer procedure or for other institute indicators in the service provider procedure.

Step 9 Certificate Request Inbound Check

The registration portal checks in the background whether the applicant has submitted a technical certificate request that was created using the security module to the Trust Center. The execution of this step is divided into the three substeps: Generation of Electronic Keys, Transfer of Files to Trust Center, and Receipt Check of Certificate Request.

Generation of Electronic Keys

A GUID transaction number (GUID for short) is now assigned, which is used as a reference between the data in the registration portal and the technical data for generating the certificate from the applicant's system. The GUID consists of 36 characters. It is recommend that you use a technically supported copy and paste of the characters to avoid spelling errors or character shifts.

GUID

 Working with the Separate Security Module

The security module is essential for applying for the electronic certificate at the ITSG Trust Center. This operation on the applicant's system is not supported by the registration portal. Therefore, you're recommended to actively log off the registration portal. Otherwise, the logoff takes place automatically.

In the security module, the key data for generating the electronic key pair (consisting of the public and private key) of the applicant must be entered manually and a certificate must be applied for. This key data must clearly match the request data entered in the registration portal. 

The following are the key data required:

· Participant number - alternatively, company number, special sender number, paying office number, etc.

· Applicant Name (Company Name)

· Contact Full Name

After entering the required information, the security module generates the key pair (consisting of public and private key) with the hash code of the request key required for certification (public key of the participant in the request file). The private key remains in the IT system of the applicant.

The generated request key is stored by the security module in a so-called Request file (p10 format) to check the hash code by the contact person for a match in a subsequent request step (example extract of a hash code: E1D07A4B.….FC781).

The security module generates a so-called safety module. Hash code file (pdf format) with the hash code in SHA256 format. This contains the following information for a unique assignment:

  • The participant number - alternatively, company number, test company number, sender number, paying office number, etc.
  • Name of the company (company name)
  • Contact Name
  • Hash Code of Request Key (SHA256 Format)

Submitting the Files to the Trust Center

After the security module has generated the electronic key and a PDF file with the hash code has been saved, the two files must be transferred to the Trust Center with the request file (for example, 12345678.p10) and the hash code. The transfer of the files to the Trust Center depends on the selected request form and the supported functions in the used software (with or without OSTC online interface).

If the software used does not support the OSTC online interface of the Trust Center, you must manually transfer the two files with the request file and the hash code (PDF file) to the trust center. Optionally, a self-declaration for a reporting office (PDF file) can be transferred in addition to the request.

Initial applications without OSTC online interface

Call up the Web address https://www.itsg-trust.de/zap/home in a browser.

Initial application without OSTC interface

 To uniquely assign the files to be transferred, you must specify the GUID transaction number (see substep Generation of Electronic Keys). After this, the three files are transferred to the Trust Center. The portal confirms the successful transfer with an internal transaction number (e.g. UP123456). 

  • Request File
  • Hash Code File
  • Self-declaration reporting office (optional) 

Initial application or online subsequent application via the OSTC online interface
For an online application using the OSTC online interface, all required application data and components (without self-declaration reporting office) are transferred automatically using the online interface. Only the GUID transaction number generated by the registration portal must be entered manually in the security module. 

After execution, the applicant receives an online order number from the OSTC system, e.g. OE123456 for online initial application or e.g. OF123456 for an online follow-up application.

Inbound Check of Certificate Request

After you have successfully transferred your files to the ITSG Trust Center either via the upload portal or the OSTC online interface, the registration portal checks in the background whether you have transferred your file with the certificate request to the Trust Center with the corresponding GUID.

The transferred request file that contains the public key of the participant key is compared with the content of the hash code file during the inbound check by the Trust Center. After receiving the request file and the hash code file, the registration portal provides the Trust Center with the complete application data for the final check. If you have logged out of the registration portal or have been automatically logged out, you will need to log in again.

Inbound check

 After a successful check from the registration portal that the certificate request with the corresponding GUID was transmitted to the Trust Center, the registration is automatically taken to the last step 10 and a release letter is sent.

Step 10 Enter a Tagging Code

After submitting the complete certificate application, the applicant receives and must complete the registration process by entering a release code in the registration portal.

The letter sent by the Trust Center to the applicant contains an activation code and the hash code of the key submitted for certification. Once the release letter has been received, the contact person or an authorized representative of the applicant must log on to the registration portal again. First, the hash code of the certification application must be visually checked for compliance with the release letter. You can then enter the activation code to complete the registration.

Enter activation code

 The Trust Center now certifies the public key transmitted by the applicant and also transfers this key to the corresponding public directories of the Trust Center. As a result, the applicant is activated as a participant in electronic data exchange with employers or electronic data exchange with service providers.

You can use the participant number and the order number on the page https://www.itsg- trust.de/all/oav.php  to register for online application tracking and view the status of your certification application.

Transferring Certified Participant Keys and Activation 

The certified public key of the applicant is stored in a certificate file (e.g. B. 12345678.p7c) for the transfer. The contact person is informed by e-mail.

The certificate file is available for download via the online application tracking on the page https://www.itsg-trust.de/all/oav.php . The transfer of the certified key must be triggered manually by the applicant.

Configuring the Key Data and Certificate File in SAP BTP Cockpit

When you configure the communication settings between your business system SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public Edition and the German pension insurance authority's system, you need to enter the key data (such as company number or sender number) as identification number. When configuring the authentication settings, the certificate file should be uploaded.

Communication setting

Authentication Setting

For more information, see the documentation Integration with a Service for Electronic Submission on the SAP Help Portal.

I hope you find this information helpful. If you have any further questions, feel free to leave a comment on this blog post or discover more information in the following documentation:

  • German euBP Files 
  • Managing Communication Settings 
  • Process-Specific Settings

entry.title: Fiori Element - Intent-Based Navigation adds unwanted query parameters and navigates to input screen
entry.content:
Intent-Based Navigation appends unwanted parameters and navigates to input screen instead of target display screen

Hello Team,

We are facing an issue with Intent-Based Navigation (IBN) for a custom semantic object/action used to open a standard display screen.

We are using an annotation structured as follows (generic form):

{
  "$Type": "UI.DataFieldWithIntentBasedNavigation",
  "SemanticObject": "SomeSemanticObject",
  "Action": "displayDocuments",
  "Value": "SomePrimaryProperty",
  "RequiresContext": true,
  "Inline": true,
  "Label": "{i18n>SomeLabel}",
  "Mapping": [
    { "LocalProperty": "PropertyA", "SemanticObjectProperty": "FieldA" },
    { "LocalProperty": "PropertyB", "SemanticObjectProperty": "FieldB" },
    { "LocalProperty": "PropertyC", "SemanticObjectProperty": "FieldC" },
    { "LocalProperty": "PropertyD", "SemanticObjectProperty": "FieldD" }
  ]
}
 

This configuration works correctly when only one mapping is provided. However, when multiple mappings are used, the IBN behavior changes unexpectedly.

Issue Observed

  1. When the IBN link is triggered, the navigation does not directly open the target display screen. Instead, it opens the initial input screen, requiring manual entry.
  2. The generated URL becomes excessively long because it includes many unrelated Object Page fields, not just the mapped ones.
  3. This issue occurs only when multiple entries exist in the Mapping array.

Example of the actual URL generated (redacted and simplified):

https://<launchpad-url>#SomeSemanticObject-displayDocuments?FieldA=...&FieldB=...&FieldC=...&FieldD=...&[hundreds of automatically-added parameters]
 

Expected Behavior

The URL should include only the explicitly mapped properties, such as:

https://<launchpad-url>#SomeSemanticObject-displayDocuments?FieldA=...&FieldB=...&FieldC=...&FieldD=...
 

No additional Object Page fields should be appended.

Impact

  • Navigation lands on the wrong screen (input instead of display).
  • Extremely long URLs due to appended parameters.
  • Behavior suggests a framework-level issue, not annotation misuse.

Request for Support

We kindly request confirmation on the following:

  • Is this a known issue or limitation in the Fiori IBN framework when multiple mappings are used?
  • Is there a workaround to ensure only mapped parameters are included in the URL?
  • Can the framework behavior be corrected so that navigation proceeds directly to the target display screen?

Any guidance or assistance in resolving this issue would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Who can access to SAP BTP ?
entry.content:

entry.title: Warehouse Management - Clear Negative Stock from 902 Stype
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I would like to request your assistance and guidance regarding an issue we are facing with negative stock appearing in storage type 902 due to a user error.

Scenario Overview:

  1. A Purchase Order was created with line item 10 (Material ABCX) and a PO quantity of 10.
  2. An inbound delivery was created, and the PGR was posted successfully. In the PO history, the 101 movement type with the material document is completed.
  3. The issue occurred when a second inbound delivery was mistakenly created and received with a quantity of 20, resulting in an additional 101 movement.
  4. Upon realizing the error, the user attempted to reverse the second material document, which posted a 102 movement.
  5. After this reversal, negative stock remains in storage type 902 under both “Stock for Putaway” and “Pick Quantity” columns. Please refer to the attachment.

Additional Notes:

The Purchase Order has no remaining open quantity to receive (Still to be Delivered = 0).  I checked LB13 and LT24 and found no open transfer orders or documents that can be processed.

At this point, I am looking for guidance on how to clear or flush out the negative stock from storage type 902 caused by this human error. I would greatly appreciate any advice, recommended steps, or corrective actions.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel - New high-volume mode
entry.content:
We should set aside the assumption that customers will not use planning layouts exceeding one million cells.
In fact, the more advanced and sophisticated the management capabilities of a customer are, the more complex their planning layouts tend to be often far beyond what we think.
We have already experienced cases where SAC could not accommodate customer requirements involving planning layouts of more than one million cells, and we ultimately had to propose BPC instead.
While there are still some limitations today particularly in planning, I Hope continuous improvements going forward.

entry.title: Re: Customize emails for e-invoices sent via DRC Cloud Ed...
entry.content:
Hi Tobi,

I had exactly the same issue. SAP does not provide an e-mail template for e-invoices like it does for the regular invoices sent via Output Management.

We solved it by implementing the BAdI _EDOC_PART_CONN_CHANGE_MAIL. With this BAdI you can add your own e-mail template text.

Hope that helps!

Best regards
David

entry.title: Spieglein, Spieglein - Einen Magischen Spiegel in Snap! Programmieren
entry.content:
In diesem Artikel befinden sich Videos, PDF-Material und Erweiterungs-Ideen für das Projekt Magischer Spiegel, bei dem mithilfe der in Snap! eingebauten Grafikeffekte Fotos oder Live-Bilder der Webcam verzerrt, gefärbt oder verwirbelt werden können. 

Das Projekt eignet sich sich gut zum Einstieg ins Programmieren, da es nur wenige Blöcke benötigt. Es kann aufgrund der angewendeten Konzepte ab der Grundschule eingesetzt werden, findet aber durchaus auch bei älteren Zielgruppen Anklang 😉. 

 

Teil 1: Grafikeffekte interaktiv auf ein Foto anwenden:

Grundidee dieses Teils ist es, mithilfe des setze _ Effekt auf _ Blocks das Kostüm eines Objekts interaktiv zu verändern. Dafür kann entweder ein Foto mit der Webcam aufgenommen werden oder ein Bild vom Computer in Snap! importiert werden. 

  • Bild mit der Webcam aufnehmen: Auf die Webcam kann unter anderem vom Kostüme-Tab zugegriffen werden. Durch Klicken auf das Kamera-Symbol öffnet sich ein Fenster, in dem die Webcam angezeigt wird. Um ein Webcam-Kostüm aufzunehmen, muss auf "Sichern" geklickt werden. "Abbrechen" schließt das Webcam-Fenster. 
    Wird die Webcam zum ersten Mal mit Snap! verwendet, muss der Zugriff erlaubt werden. Je nach Browser erscheint ein Pop-Up Fenster, aus dem der Zugriff auf die Webcam gewährt werden kann. Ist der Zugriff nicht erlaubt, ist der Webcam-Knopf ausgegraut. Dann kann die Seite einfach noch einmal geladen werden, damit erneut nach dem Zugriff gefragt wird. 
    Klicke auf den "Kostüme"-Tab und dort auf die Webcam, um die Kamera zu öffnen (links), beim ersten Mal muss der Zugriff erlaubt werden (Mitte, Bild von Google Chrome, Pop-Up sieht je nach Browser unterschiedlich aus), dann kann durch Klicken auf "Sichern" ein Foto-Kostüm gemacht werden (rechts), "Abbrechen" schließt das Fenster mit der Kamera.

 

  • Bild importieren: Wenn keine Webcam vorhanden ist, oder andere Bilder genutzt werden sollen, können auch einfach Bilder vom Computer importiert werden. Klicke dafür auf das Dateimenü und wähle Importieren... Es öffnet sich ein Fenster, in dem du zum gewünschten Bild navigieren kannst. 

 

Material für den ersten Teil des Projekts:

  • Diese Videoerklärung führt Schritt für Schritt durch das Programm:
    https://youtu.be/H9bsrODOqjs 
  • Diese Lernkarte erklärt detailliert den Ablauf des Projekts:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/YxtXrKn?rc=10&doi=SAP1265363 
  • Dieses Starterprojekt enthält nur die benötigten Blöcke für beide Teile des magischen Spiegels. Reduzierte Starterprojekte eignen sich besonders für den Einsatz mit jüngeren Kindern, da sie die kognitive Belastung reduzieren, aber auch die kreativen Möglichkeiten einschränken: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Starter&editMode&noRun 
  • Dieses Lösungsprojekt enthält das Programm für den ersten Teil des magischen Spiegels. Als Effekte wurden Farbe und Fischauge ausgewählt. Das Projekt wird mit der grünen Fahne gestartet, Drücken der Leertaste setzt die Grafikeffekte zurück. 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part1 

 

Hinweis für die Nutzung mit Tablets:

Werden für das Programmieren oder Vorführen des Projekts Tablets genutzt, muss ein extra Schritt ausgeführt werden.

Am Computer kann die Maus x- bzw. Maus y- Position, über die die Effekte gesteuert werden, immer ausgelesen werden. Bei Tablets ist das nur möglich, wenn ein tatsächliches Touch-Event stattfindet, d.h. der Finger oder ein Stift das Tablet berührt. Damit ist dann auch immer ein Klick verbunden. 

Führt man diesen Klick auf dem Foto aus, hebt man das Objekt von der Bühne an und zieht es mit der Bewegung mit. Das kann verhindert werden, indem man das Häkchen vor der Einstellung greifbar entfernt. Dann kann das Objekt nur noch programmatisch, nicht mehr durch Klicken mit der Maus entfernt werden. 

Ist das Häkchen vor "greifbar" gesetzt, kann das Objekt mit Mausklick bewegt werden. Wird das Häkchen entfernt, kann das Objekt nur noch durch das Programm selbst bewegt werden.

 

Teil 2: Magischen Spiegel mit Bewegtbild bauen:

Im zweiten Teil des Projekts wird die Webcam fortlaufend auf ein Kostüm projiziert. Dadurch entsteht der Eindruck eines Live-Video-Feeds auf dem Spiegel-Objekt. Dieser kann dann wieder mit den Grafikeffekten bearbeitet werden. 

 

Materialien für den zweiten Teil des Projekts:

  • In diesem Video findest du eine Schritt für Schritt Anleitung für den zweiten Teil:
    https://youtu.be/9moiIRrqPCI
  • Diese Lernkarte enthält eine detaillierte Anleitung für das Projekt:
    https://d.dam.sap.com/a/Uao4FKG?rc=10&doi=SAP1265850 
  • Dieses Lösungsprojekt enthält das gesamte Programm für Teil 2: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part2 

 

Erweitere das Projekt:

Zusätzlich zu den eingebauten Grafikeffekten können weitere Ideen im Projekt umgesetzt werden. Die Blöcke hierfür sind nicht im Starterprojekt enthalten. So können Blöcke ein- und ausgeblendet werden:

Um selbst Blöcke zu verbergen, kannst du mit Rechtsklick auf die Palette klicken und die Option „Blöcke verbergen…“ auswählen. Dadurch öffnet sich ein Dialogfenster mit allen verfügbaren Blöcken.

Darin kannst du die Blöcke, die du ausblenden möchtest, einzeln auswählen, indem du das Kästchen davor anklickst – oder du machst einen Rechtsklick im Dialogfenster und wählst die Option „nicht verwendete“. Das ist besonders nützlich, wenn du nur die Blöcke für ein bestimmtes Projekt brauchst: Du kannst einfach dein gewünschtes Ergebnis bauen und anschließend alle ungenutzten Blöcke verbergen.

Nachdem du auf OK klickst, enthält die Palette nur noch die nicht-ausgewählten Blöcke.

Falls du ausgeblendete Blöcke wieder anzeigen möchtest, kannst du erneut den Dialog „Blöcke verbergen...“ öffnen und das Häkchen vor dem jeweiligen Block entfernen. Möchtest du alle Blöcke anzeigen, kannst du im Dialogfenster mit Rechtsklick die Option "nichts" auswählen und dann auf OK klicken. 

Dadurch werden alle Blöcke wieder in der Palette sichtbar.

 

Das Bild verzerren: 

Mithilfe des strecke-Blocks können die Kostüme eines Objekts verzerrt werden. Der strecke-Block hat drei Eingaben, das zu streckende Kostüm und die Streckung bzw. Stauchung in x- und y-Richtung. Wählt man für beide Richtungen 100 aus, passiert nichts, das Kostüm behält seine aktuelle Streckung bei. Wählt man für die x-Richtung Werte größer als 100 % (z.B. 200, s.u.) wird das Kostüm breiter. Bei Werten kleiner als 100% in x-Richtung würde es schmaler werden. Werte kleiner als 100% in y-Richtung machen das Kostüm flacher (z.B. 80, s.u.), bei Werten größer als 100% in y-Richtung würde das Kostüm höher werden. 

links: Originalkostüm "Ei", rechts: Kostüm "Ei" gestreckt auf 200% in x-Richtung - daher breiter, und gestaucht auf 80% in y-Richtung - daher flacher.

Um das Bild der Webcam für den magischen Spiegel zu verzerren, muss noch ein kleiner Umweg gegangen werden. Fügt man statt dem Kostüm "Ei" nämlich direkt den Video Snap auf selbst ein, wird das Kostüm in diesem Fall immer breiter und flacher, da die Abmessungen des Objekts jedes Mal, wenn der Schnappschuss als Kostüm angezogen wird, auf x: 200% und y: 80% gestreckt bzw. gestaucht werden - in anderen Worten, bei jedem neuen Schnappschuss wird das Objekt doppelt so breit und 0.8 Mal so hoch wie vorher. 

Das Kostüm wird jedes Mal gestreckt, wenn der Webcam-Schnappschuss als Kostüm angezogen wird, wenn das Kostüm nicht vorher auf die Originalmaße zurückgesetzt wurde.

Bevor das Kostüm Video Snap auf selbst angezogen wird, sollte deshalb wieder zurück auf das ursprüngliche Kostüm "Ei" gewechselt werden. Damit bleibt die Streckung dann immer bei x: 200%, y: 80% der Original-Ausmaße. 

Bevor der Video Snap als Kostüm angezogen wird und auf x: 200% und y: 80% gestreckt bzw. gestaucht wird, wird auf das ursprüngliche Kostüm "Ei" gewechselt.

 

Das Bild spiegeln und duplizieren:

Ebenfalls mit dem strecke-Block kann das Kostüm auch in verschiedene Richtungen gespiegelt werden, wenn man negative Eingaben für die x- und y-Richtung wählt. Ist die Eingabe für die x-Richtung beispielsweise -100% wird das Kostüm horizontal gespiegelt. Bei einer Streckung in y-Richtung von -100% wird es vertikal gespiegelt. 

links: Video Snap auf selbst, Mitte: Video Snap auf selbst, horizontal gespiegelt durch Streckung in x-Richtung auf -100%. rechts: Video Snap auf selbst vertikal gespiegelt durch Streckung in y-Richtung auf -100%

Nur das Spiegeln alleine ist noch nicht besonders interessant. Lustig wird es, wenn man gespiegelte und nicht gespiegelte Objekte übereinander anzeigt.

Erstelle zwei Objekte und bewege sie an dieselbe Stelle. Das untere der beiden Objekte trägt einfach dauerhaft den Video Snap auf selbst als Kostüm. Das obenliegende Objekt soll ebenfalls dauerhaft das Bild der Webcam als Kostüm tragen, aber horizontal oder vertikal gespiegelt. Dann kannst du mithilfe des Durchsichtigkeit-Effekts das obenliegende Objekt semi-transparent machen. Beide Versionen, die gespiegelte und nicht-gespiegelte sind nun gleichzeitig sichtbar. 

Du kannst leicht bis zu 4 verschieden gespiegelte Objekte übereinander anzeigen, nur musst du dann den Durchsichtigkeit-Effekt für jedes Objekt dementsprechend anpassen. 

Zwei Objekte übereinander, die beide jeweils dauerhaft den Video Snap auf selbst als Kostüm anziehen. Beim oberen Objekt ist das Kostüm in x-Richtung auf -100% gestreckt, also horizontal gespiegelt. Zusätzlich ist beim oberen Objekt der Durchsichtigkeitseffekt auf 50 gesetzt, dadurch sind beide Versionen, Original und horizontal gespiegeltes Kostüm gleichzeitig sichtbar.

 

Das Bild drehen:

Der magische Spiegel kann auch gedreht werden. Das Bild der Webcam wird dann jeweils in die Richtung angezeigt, in die das Objekt gerade gedreht ist. Zeigt das Objekt Richtung 90, ist es "richtig herum", d.h. der Hals ist unten. Setzt man die Richtung beispielsweise auf 45, ist das ganze Objekt und damit auch der Video Snap darauf um 45 Grad gedreht. Der Hals zeigt nun nach unten rechts. 

Um die Richtung immer zu ändern, kann zum Beispiel ein Skript genutzt werden, das das Objekt dauerhaft langsam dreht. 

Links: Video Snap wenn das Objekt Richtung 90 zeigt. Mitte: Video Snap wenn das Objekt Richtung 45 Grad zeigt. Rechts: Skript, mit dem sich das Objekt dauerhaft um 0.2 Grad dreht.

 

Die Erweiterungen ausprobieren:

links: mithilfe des "strecke" Blocks verzerrtes Spiegelbild, mitte: zwei Objekte übereinander, das obere ist transparent (Durchsichtigkeit-Effekt 50) und mithilfe des "strecke" Blocks (x: - 100, y: 100) gespiegelt, rechts: das Objekt dreht sich langsam um 0.2 Grad , dadurch kann beispielsweise der Hals links an der Seite sein.

Teste die drei Erweiterungen im folgenden Lösungs-Projekt: 
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Extension 

Drücke die grüne Fahne, um alle Spiegel zu starten. Dann drücke die Taste der Spiegel-Nummer, um die jeweilige Erweiterung ein- und auszublenden.
Taste 1 für den Verzerrspiegel
Taste 2 für den "gespiegelten" Spiegel
Taste 3 für den drehenden Spiegel 

 

Exkurs: Die Webcam auf anderen Objekten anzeigen - Tipps, Tricks und weitere Ideen

Die Video Snap auf selbst Funktion gibt ein Bild zurück, das den Teil der Webcam anzeigt, der sich hinter dem ausführenden Objekt (selbst) befindet. Das Bild hat die Form des aktuellen Kostüms, egal ob das Kostüm selbst gemalt wurde oder aus der Kostümbibliothek oder vom Computer importiert wurde. Das Ganze funktioniert auch, wenn die Videotransparenz auf 100 gesetzt wurde, die Webcam auf der Bühne also unsichtbar ist. 

Der Video Snap der Webcam wird auf dem Kostüm von Alonzo, das das Objekt trägt, das die Funktion ausführt, angezeigt.

Manchmal ist das Kostüm zu klein, um den gewünschten Teil der Webcam anzuzeigen. In diesem Fall passt auf Alonzo nur ein Auge, nicht das gesamte Gesicht. Auch das Vergrößern des Objekts beispielsweise von Größe 100 auf Größe 250 verändert den Teil der Webcam nicht, der auf dem Objekt angezeigt wird. Genau wie das Objekt wird auch das Bild der Webcam auf dem Objekt vergrößert, der gezeigte Ausschnitt bleibt gleich.

links ist das Objekt in Größe 100 mit einem Video Snap Kostüm angezeigt. Rechts daneben dasselbe Objekt mit Größe 250. Dabei wird insgesamt alles vergrößert, der angezeigte Ausschnitt der Webcam bleibt beim Vergrößern des Objekts also gleich.

Möchtest du den Ausschnitt der Kamera vergrößern, musst du die Größe des Kostüms verändern, ohne die Größe des Objekts selbst anzupassen. Dafür kannst du das Skript, das in der folgenden Grafik angezeigt wird verwenden. Am Skript, das die Webcam auf dem Objekt anzeigt, muss nichts verändert werden. 

Oben ist das Objekt in Größe 100 mit seinem Kostüm angezeigt. Rechts daneben ist das Ergebnis des “Video Snap auf selbst” Blocks für dieses Objekt zu sehen. Unten ist dasselbe Objekt mit vergrößertem Kostüm zu sehen. Durch das links stehende Skript wird die Größe des Objekts zuerst auf 280 gesetzt. Dann wird es auf die Bühne gestempelt. Die Größe des Objekts wird danach auf 100 zurückgesetzt. Die gestempelten Abdrücke (Malspuren) können als Kostüm angezogen werden. Das Objekt hat nun eine Größe von 100 aber mit einem deutlich vergrößerten Kostüm. Dadurch wird auch der Ausschnitt der Webcam, der auf dem Kostüm angezeigt wird, verändert.

Damit stehen dir viele weitere Ideen aus dem Bereich Media Computation mit Bildern offen. Wie wäre es beispielsweise mit eigenen Grafikeffekten, wie dem Negativ-Effekt, der die Farben invertiert. 
Schon von Dithering gehört? Dabei handelt es sich um eine Technik, bei der aus wenigen Farben (in diesem Fall einem einzigen Grünton) eine größere Farbtiefe erzeugt werden kann (in diesem Fall entsteht durch Punkte in unterschiedlicher Größe ein "Grünstufen" Effekt).
Oder wie wäre es mit einer personalisierten Version des berühmten Kunstwerks "Schotter" von Georg Nees?

Werde selbst kreativ beziehungsweise wirf einen Blick auf die weiteren Materialien zum Thema Media Computation  🎼 📜 🎥

entry.title: Re: Enable Posting of Supplier Invoices with Zero Amount
entry.content:
Dear @Chris1973 ,

Thank you for your follow-up.

To clarify the scenario: we are referring to a "Netting" or "Clearing" invoice where the document contains both Debit and Credit line items that mathematically offset each other, resulting in a final Gross Amount (Vendor Liability) of 0.00 EUR.

However, these line items are subject to VAT, and we need to record the tax information correctly in our VAT Registers, even if the payment amount is zero.

Here is the specific Double-Entry (Journal Entry) structure for this requirement:

Scenario: Invoice with Offsetting Items (e.g. Service Charge with immediate Full Rebate/Credit Memo)

Gross Invoice Amount (Vendor Line): 0.00 EUR

Posting Logic:

Debit [S]: Expense Account (Cost) -> Amount: +1,000.00 EUR (Tax Code V1 - 22%)

Credit [H]: Expense/Clearing Account (Rebate/Credit) -> Amount: -1,000.00 EUR (Tax Code V1 - 22%)

Debit [S]: Input VAT -> Amount: +220.00 EUR

Credit [H]: Input VAT (Correction) -> Amount: -220.00 EUR

Credit [H]: Vendor / Supplier Account -> Balance: 0.00 EUR

The system correctly calculates the taxes on the line items, and the mathematical sum of the document is zero. However, we are currently blocked by message M8 140 ("Invoiced amount must be greater than zero").

We need this restriction lifted to process these standard accounting settlements.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Homogeneous Update and Copy to SAP Cloud using RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s rapidly evolving SAP landscape, customers are increasingly looking for seamless ways to upgrade and migrate their systems to leverage the full potential of SAP S/4HANA and the cloud. As part of the Early Adopter Program, I had the opportunity to work hands-on with the Transition Workbench tool to perform an upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FP03 and subsequently execute a migration to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP).

In this blog, I share my real-world experience from this project — detailing the Update and Tenant Copy methods in SAP BTP Cloud Cockpit, how the Transition Workbench helped streamline the process, and the step-by-step approach I followed to carry out the upgrade and migration successfully. This write-up is designed to help consultants and customers alike understand the practical aspects, challenges, and best practices of such transformations.

I would like to take a moment to recognize and sincerely appreciate the efforts and valuable technical advisory of Ravikiran Chikati, Barathwaj, Arvind, Srivastava, Piyush and Klumpp, Fabian.  

Overview: Update and Copy to SAP Cloud Cockpit

This process describes how an on-premises SAP S/4HANA or SAP Business Suite (SOH) system is upgraded and replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition environment using the Transition Workbench and the Update & Copy to Cloud Cockpit approach.

The workflow begins with provisioning a skeleton target system and a migration server in the SAP Cloud environment (steps 1 & 2). The Transition Workbench acts as an intermediate layer to streamline preparation, replication, and upgrade tasks (steps 3–5).

On the source side, preparation steps are executed, the SUM tool performs the in-place upgrade, and the download directories are copied between the migration server and the source system (steps 4, 6, 7 & 8).

After ramp-down activities (step 9), the upgrade is completed, and the system is switched back to the main instance (steps 10 & 12). Finally, ECS post-processing ensures that the migrated and upgraded system is ready for productive use (step 13).

This phased approach—covering Pre-Requisite Checks, Software Download, Preparation, Replication, Downtime Finalization, and Post-Processing—helps customers move from an on-premises S/4HANA or SOH system to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP) efficiently and with minimal risk.

 

Introduction

In today’s rapidly evolving SAP landscape, customers are increasingly looking for seamless ways to upgrade and migrate their systems to leverage the full potential of SAP S/4HANA and the cloud. As part of the Early Adopter Program, I had the opportunity to work hands-on with the Transition Workbench tool to perform an upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FP03 and subsequently execute a migration to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP).

In this blog, I share my real-world experience from this project — detailing the Update and Tenant Copy methods in SAP BTP Cloud Cockpit, how the Transition Workbench helped streamline the process, and the step-by-step approach I followed to carry out the upgrade and migration successfully. This write-up is designed to help consultants and customers alike understand the practical aspects, challenges, and best practices of such transformations.

I would like to take a moment to recognize and sincerely appreciate the efforts and valuable technical advisory of Ravikiran Chikati, Barathwaj, Arvind, Srivastava, Piyush and Klumpp, Fabian.  

Overview: Update and Copy to SAP Cloud Cockpit

This process describes how an on-premises SAP S/4HANA or SAP Business Suite (SOH) system is upgraded and replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition environment using the Transition Workbench and the Update & Copy to Cloud Cockpit approach.

The workflow begins with provisioning a skeleton target system and a migration server in the SAP Cloud environment (steps 1 & 2). The Transition Workbench acts as an intermediate layer to streamline preparation, replication, and upgrade tasks (steps 3–5).

On the source side, preparation steps are executed, the SUM tool performs the in-place upgrade, and the download directories are copied between the migration server and the source system (steps 4, 6, 7 & 8).

After ramp-down activities (step 9), the upgrade is completed, and the system is switched back to the main instance (steps 10 & 12). Finally, ECS post-processing ensures that the migrated and upgraded system is ready for productive use (step 13).

This phased approach—covering Pre-Requisite Checks, Software Download, Preparation, Replication, Downtime Finalization, and Post-Processing—helps customers move from an on-premises S/4HANA or SOH system to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP) efficiently and with minimal risk.

 

Pre-requisite

Provision/Validation of DNS names in RISE environment

Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

  1. Provision the Migration VM and the Target System

You will receive the Migration VM details together with the handover of the target landscape details.​

Cockpit-Independent Preparatory Actions

Preparation activities required both from ECS and users to access and work with the "system transition workbench"

  • Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

The "RISE with SAP system transition workbench" ("system transition workbench") is installed by ECS on a so-called Migration VM. After preparing the Migration VM, ECS hands it over to the migration partner.

Early Adopter program, are not provided by default on the Migration VM

  • Preparatory actions to be performed by Users
    • The workbench requires access to internet, preconfigured by the user's proxy.
    • Remote Function Call (RFC)
    • RFC requests are used for the communication to the application servers.
  • Migration VM must have connection to the source system to make RFC calls. the following source system parameters are required:
  • DDIC user in client 000 of the source system
  • Instance host
  • Domain
  • Instance number
  • Access to Services and Tools
    • The "system transition workbench" needs to access to the following:
    • The source system and the target SAP HANA database using SQL
    • The Maintenance Planner
    • The analytics service
    • The Software Download Service (SDS)
 

General Network Requirements

The "system transition workbench" has the following network requirements on the Migration VM:

  • Connection to source and target database using SQL ports
  • Connection to the source application server using remote function call (RFC)
  • Connection to the Maintenance Planner, SAP download services, CRLbag service, and analytics tools

Requirement for Maintenance Planner and HANA Replication

  • The source system must be known to the Maintenance Planner
  • Users must manually create a transaction in the Maintenance Planner
  • Validate all HANA Replication related parameters are applied on source and target database (Refer Pre-req sheet)
  • Validate if Log mode of Source to be Normal and keep monitoring log volume size to store logs to be replicated.
  • Validate if
  1. a) Auto failover should be disabled.
  2. b) Disable Database Hooks: Hooks are HA/DR providers which sends information to initiate auto failover. These can be disabled from global.ini file.
  • Validate if nameserver Service ports needs to be opened in Source System and target system, Range: 3<inst_id><service port> or 3<inst_id>XX. Telnet test can be performed to validated if ports are open

 

 

Created the ticket to enable the Migration VM from ECS. You will receive the mail after enabling the Migration VM from ECS. TWB tool has been installed on the migration server. Make sure you are on the latest Version before starting the project 

RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench Version: 0.36.1

 

 SAP System Transition Workbench
Once Enabled the Transition Workbench login to VDI or Citrix of customer access the Below URL

Note: LT1 Migration VM is meant for customer it can be accessed from the Customer Network only

https://<hostname>. <domain_name>:1129/lmsl/slocon/docs/index.html 

Login with user sapadm, if password not available reset at the OS level to get the password.

Create the Vault to secure the password storage, a KeePass Vault is to be created.       It will be encrypted with the vault password you enter.

 

Start the Uptime Phase

Uptime Phase has 3 Steps

  1. Pre-requisite Checks
  2. Download
  3. Preparation and Replication
 

Pre-requisites Checks

Start the Task 1.1: Pre-requisite Checks for Homogenous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

Below are the Parameter which needed for Tenant Copy

Source System

 

Target System

Confirm the setting can be applied to the target database of the productive system

Clear the result with error

Perform the backup of the Source and Target Database within the last 24 hours

Uninstall the LCAPPS and AFL components from the source database as it is not installed on the Target Database

Apply the SAP Note 3409764 in the Source System

Confirm the SAP Note has been applied on the Source System and proceed further

Software Download

Start the Task 2.1: Software Download

Preparation and Replication

Start the Task 3.1: Pre-requisite for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

 





Start the Task 3.2: Initialize and Monitor SAP HANA Replication

 

Execute the below SQL Statement to check the Replication Status

SELECT DATABASE_NAME, SOURCE_HOST, TARGET_HOST, REPLICATION_STATUS, REPLICATION_STATUS_DETAILS, LAST_LOG_POSITION, LAST_LOG_POSITION_TIME, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION_TIME from SYS_DATABASES.M_DATABASE_REPLICA_STATISTICS

Once Replication Status in ACTIVE Status

Copy the Downloaded Directory from LT1 (Migration VM) to Source System

Copy the addons into this Download Directory

Start the SUM on the Source System

SUM Uptime Activities

cd /usr/sap/CS5/Cycle2/SUM/abap/

./SUMSTART confighostagent SID

 

SUM URL - https://<hostname>.<domainname>:1129/lmsl/sumabap/SID/slui

Extraction

 
Configuration Phase

 

Checks Phase

 

Prep-processing Phase

 

Ramp-down Activities Before downtime

Execution Phase

 

Post Processing After Downtime

 

Finalize Replication Steps

 

Start the Downtime Phase in this phase you have two steps

  1. Finalize
  2. Post-Processing

 

Start the Task 1.1: Finalize Tenant Replication for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP HANA

 

Start the Task 2.1: Post-Processing

 

Confirm and proceed further to complete the Transition workbench

Perform the Post Activities

Execute the Report SHDB_MIGRATION_CHECK

 

Manual Post Processing

 

Create the SR Ticket to Switch Application back to Main instance after the Migration

Update hdbuserstore and Check R3trans -d / -x (Validate connection to DB is working on all APPS)

Updated as part of the Switch Main Instance SR

 

Perform the Post Activities

Silent Data Migration

Go to transaction SDM_MON -> Current Client Info

Run SJOBREPO -> SAP_SDM_EXECUTOR_POSTPROCESSING

Handover to ECS Post Processing

entry.title: Issue Verifiable Credentials for the Swiss E-ID environment on the SAP Business Technology Platform
entry.content:
Setting Up the swiyu Generic Issuer on SAP BTP

Having your ID, drivers license, professional certification, insurance confirmation all on your phone can make your life easier. With the Swiss E-ID infrastructure, that’s possible. Both government bodies and non-government organizations (reads: companies or yourself) can use the trust infrastructure of the Swiss E-ID to issue their own certificates.

Building on our first blog post on verifying the Swiss E-ID, this article now explores the next step: how to issue your own digital credentials using the swiyu Generic Issuer. If you haven’t read the verification blog yet, we recommend starting there for background on the architecture and trust model.

In this post, we walk through how to deploy the swiyu Generic Issuer – the official reference implementation for issuing verifiable credentials – on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This allows your business applications to create and deliver swiyu-compatible credentials (such as identity proofs, age confirmations, or membership cards) directly into users’ wallets. The result: a streamlined, secure, and privacy-preserving alternative to traditional ID checks or manual credentialing workflows.

Business Relevance

Many business processes require issuing credentials. For example, companies issuing digital certificates to new employees (like an employee ID), to customers (membership cards or warranties), credentials of certifications, or to minors (age-restriction certificates). This involved validating pictures of paper documents with tedious validation steps. With swiyu’s infrastructure, the Generic Issuer can create signed digital credentials that go straight into a user’s swiyu wallet; these credentials are cryptographically signed, ensuring they are tamper-proof and digitally verifiable by anyone, and crucially, empower the certificate holder to selectively decide exactly which information they share with the verifier. This streamlines workflows like HR onboarding, verification of certificates, KYC (know your customer, the identification of legal or natural persons in the financial industry), or age checks: issuing is done via trusted digital channels without disclosing extra data, since the user’s identity attributes never leave their device

Architecture

The swiyu Generic Issuer is a government-provided reference implementation bundling all the core functionality needed for credential issuance. It runs as your own server (for example on SAP BTP) with a backing database, and it interacts with the swiyu trust infrastructure. The issuer service uses a Decentralized Identifier (DID) registered in the swiyu Base Registry (holding its public keys) and is listed in the Trust Registry (for trust statements). When issuing a credential, the issuer talks to a user’s swiyu wallet via standard APIs, and to the swiyu Trust Registry to publish status updates (e.g. revocation). The holder’s wallet only releases attributes to the issuer with user consent. The overall system is illustrated below:

Figure 1: Basic architecture of the swiyu-issuer implementation on SAP BTP

 

Setting Up Your Own Issuer on SAP BTP

Prerequisites:

  • Cloud foundry space
  • PostgreSQL Entitlement
  • Registered application / business on the FOITTs platform (for details see here)

Now deploy the Generic Issuer service on SAP BTP:

  1. Provision Database: In the SAP BTP Cockpit (or CF CLI), create a PostgreSQL service instance in your space. Once provisioned, generate a service key to retrieve credentials (host, port, username, password) for your application.
  2. Prepare Environment Variables: On your local machine, create a manifest.yml for Cloud Foundry push and a .env file (or use cf set-env) defining the needed variables. (E.g. ISSUER_ID, EXTERNAL_URL, SWIYU_PARTNER_ID, etc.)
    1. Be aware that you specify the fields of your to-issue credential in the “issuer-metadata”.
  3. Status Registry Credentials: the SWIYU_STATUS_REGISTRY_* keys, tokens and URLs obtained from the API portal (customer key/secret, refresh token, OAuth token URL, status API URL).
  4. Verification Methods: the DID’s verification method identifiers for status and SD-JWT signing (from the DID log). For example, DID_STATUS_LIST_VERIFICATION_METHOD must match the DID assertion key used for the status list.
  1. Deploy the Issuer App: Set the Docker image for swiyu-issuer. (FOITT provides ready images on Docker Hub.) Use cf push with your manifest to deploy the issuer. After pushing, the issuer’s management API and Swagger UI will be available.
  2. Initialize Status List: Before issuing any credential, the issuer must initialize a status list slot. Call the issuer’s management API endpoint  – save this URL and ID for use when issuing credentials. This step creates the on-chain slot needed to track revocations.
  3. Access and Secure the API: You can explore the issuer’s endpoints using its built-in Swagger UI (e.g. at https://<your-app>/swagger-ui.html). All calls for creating offers and checking status can be tested here. For any management or production deployment, secure the API (e.g. via a fixed asymmetric key or OAuth2) to prevent unauthorized issuance. (Note: The default configuration is for experimentation; for production-grade security consult FOITT’s deployment guide.)
  4. Optional: Frontend Integration: For user convenience, you may build a simple front-end (e.g. a SAP UI5 or CAP service) that interacts with the issuer API. In a PoC we integrated JWT-based authentication with a UI5 app so end-users can easily trigger and view issuance. This is not strictly required, but can streamline the UX when customers interact with the issuance flow.

Issuing Credentials

With the issuer running and initialized, you can now issue credentials. The general flow is:

  • Your application triggers a credential offer: call the issuer’s POST /management/api/credentials endpoint with the credential data. This includes fields like credential_subject_data (e.g. name, birthdate) and the "status_lists" array containing the statusRegistryUrl from before.
  • The response will contain a management_id and an offer_deeplink URL. The latter is a QR-code deep link for the swiyu wallet. Render this (e.g. as a QR code in your web page). When the wallet scans it, the holder sees an issuance request (prompt to accept or decline).
  • Revocation/Suspension: Later, if needed (e.g. a credential should be cancelled or suspended), update its status via PATCH with credentialStatus=REVOKED or SUSPENDED. This updates the public status list so verifiers know the credential is no longer valid.

To illustrate: after issuing an offer, the terminal shows something like

{"management_id":"abc123", "offer_deeplink":"swiyu-issue://?client_id=..."}

You turn that deep link into a QR code and scan it with the swiyu wallet. The wallet then prompts the user to accept the new credential. Once accepted, the issuer marks it as ISSUED in the registry. The user’s device now holds a signed verifiable credential (e.g. their new digital e-ID).

Figure 2: Credential offer on the users swiyu-wallet

 

 

Conclusion

By following these steps, you will have your own swiyu Generic Issuer running on SAP BTP, registered as a valid issuer in the Swiss trust registry, and ready to issue QR-based e-ID credentials. In practice, this lets you integrate trusted digital credential issuance into any business process – from HR identity checks, to age verification in e‑commerce, to verification of certifications, to KYC/AML flows – without costly manual ID or document scans. All credential data remains cryptographically protected and on the user’s device, while your service simply asks the swiyu trust infrastructure to verify the issuer’s identity and handle revocations.

Next Steps: Be sure to, if you haven’t yet, check out our blog post on setting up and deploying the swiyu Generic Verifier on SAP BTP. Together, these components complete the swiyu ecosystem on SAP BTP, enabling fully digital, privacy-preserving identity and credential workflows.

entry.title: From Vision to Reality: Our 2025 Milestones in AI, Cloud, and Industry Transformation
entry.content:
As I reflect on 2025, I am proud of what our team accomplished by aligning with the broader priorities shaping SAP and our industry. We adopted an AI-first approach, accelerated the adoption of S/4HANA, and made a significant shift towards cloud- and data-driven business models. This year, we transitioned from strategy to execution by embedding AI and automation into our core processes, modernizing our infrastructure with hybrid and private cloud strategies, and unifying our data on platforms like SAP BTP and the Business Data Cloud.

  • Field logistics & Joule: We launched the “Where is my stuff” Joule use case in Q3. Bringing mobility and AI into a customer-facing scenario delivered real field visibility improvements—and the engagement we saw at ASUG events, plus our new AWS partnership, validated the demand for practical, production-ready AI agents. Our active participation in ACOGE workstreams for Finance‑JVA and Field Logistics helped shape roadmaps that matter to customers.
  • Upstream Hydrocarbon Accounting & Management (UHAM): We made tangible progress to help customers adopt clean‑core and fit‑to‑standard approaches. Deliverables in 2025 included new APIs and CDS views, additional compliance reports, and features that accelerate S/4HANA migration—specifically, Legacy PPA/PPN handling and PRA integration with Treasury to enable ongoing payment processing. We also introduced UHAM BDC data products for well completions, volumes, and accounting-document data. Early AI work, such as Zero‑Touch Data Entry, is being developed to capture key data from plant statements and reduce manual effort.
  • Downstream & Retail (SDM and RFNO): SDM moved closer to an industry-agnostic offering, with better forecasting, automatic trip creation, and smarter automation that will broaden its market fit starting in 2026. RFNO made strong strides toward replacing legacy SSR—improving service‑station network, settlement and aggregation processes, and AI-driven pricing logic that supports autonomous learning and automated price population at the pump.
  • sto360 (STO excellence): sto360 shifted from a powerful point tool to a strategic, SAP-aligned STO platform. This year’s enhancements—turnaround planning workspaces, automated scope definition, risk-based prioritization, contractor orchestration, digital QA/QC, and SAP BTP analytics—are already delivering better schedule reliability, cost control, and execution visibility for customers across Oil & Gas, Utilities, Chemicals, and Mining.

What this means going into 2026: the cleaner core integrations, open APIs, stronger partner ecosystem, and practical AI deployments we delivered in 2025 set the stage for deeper S/4HANA alignment, expanded Joule use cases, broader SDM availability, RFNO readiness for marketplace needs, and continued sto360 innovation.

In-person industry events:
I’m grateful we connected in 2025 at

  • SBN Energy Day — 26 March, Stavanger (Equinor), Norway
  • Baker Hughes Annual Meeting — 2–4 Feb, Florence, Italy
  • SAP for Energy and Utilities Conference — 8–10 April, Rotterdam, Netherlands
  • SAPPHIRE Orlando — 19–21 May, Orlando, Florida, USA
  • SAPPHIRE Madrid — 26–28 May, Madrid, Spain
  • Reuters Events: Data Driven Oil & Gas — 24–25 June, Houston, Texas, USA
  • OKC Innovation Day — 23 July
  • Total Plant Maintenance — 9–11 Sept, Dubai, UAE
  • ASUG Best Practices — 6–8 Oct, Houston, Texas, USA
  • SAP for Asset and Service Management Conference — 8–9 Oct, Rome, Italy
  • NA Energy Capital Assembly — 22–23 Oct, Houston, Texas, USA

Thank you to every customer, partner, and SAP colleague who brought energy, feedback, and partnership to these efforts—your collaboration made this year’s outcomes possible.

Wishing you and your loved ones a joyful holiday season and a peaceful, prosperous Christmas!

entry.title: Healthcare integration - Patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
In this blog, I'll give a sneak preview on various integration possibilities between Hospital Information Systems and an ERP system. I'll go into details about an integration package which creates patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. In the healthcare context, integration of patient data is important with most of the business process inside a hospital revolves around the patient. Before I go into details of the integration package, let’s first understand a few key words and use case.

Key words

SAP Cloud ERP Private refers to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

SAP BTP refers to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Integration Packages are a set of preconfigured integration artifacts for specific business process between various systems involved. 

Business Partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private is a central master data object that represents an organization, person, or group of people showing a business relationship.

FHIR refers to Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources. FHIR® is the registered trademarks of Health Level Seven International.

Perspective

There are many use cases where hospital data is available in an EMR (Electronic Medical Record) system like treatment, staffs and care-givers, billing and claims and so on. This data needs to be exchanged with SAP Cloud ERP Private to do business processes.

We need data exchange to improve agility and clarity for effective decision-making and to adapt for business transformation correctly.

Patient as a business partner is just one of the integration use cases. The integration package which I talk about in this blog offers template and guidance to integrate more such data. Entities like departments, vendors, personnel (Doctors and Hospital staffs), insurance, and so on, are some examples of data needed for integration. Such data integration will help in realizing business processes for finance, supply chain, workforce management and so on.

SAP Health Data Services for FHIR supports all the FHIR resources and serves as a domain model for data integration between EMR and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use Case

Why we need to represent the patient as a business partner? Let’s consider billing as an example at the hospital, where a patient could be a self-payer or a co-payer. We need to do Account Receivable management in SAP Cloud ERP Private for payment tracking and collection.  

Hence, the patient needs to be kept as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Onboarding - SAP Health Data Services for FHIR

For integration to be established, you need to have a key BTP service which is SAP Health Data Services for FHIR. For details, refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/f64d5f2b858042f791b64bdd4094df22/872ceb743a38498bb960b916de6cde5d.html

This onboarding steps are made simple using the BTP booster which automates all the onboarding steps for you, and you can refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/4613ca2972b540168ab4e03bf72023d7/de0e3033cda5477691db3bd521bbb163.html

Another step is to configure the patient resource in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR by profiling the patient resource. Refer the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/f754dd80490a41c996927fac6116feba.html

Setting up access control in cloud connector

We need this step to establish secure communication between SAP BTP and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use the following link to complete the setup of access control in the cloud connector.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/de25990e3bfb40c29cdc2a6df49fd63e.html

Finding an Integration Package

  • Go to https://api.sap.com/ and select “Integration”.

 

  • Then in the following tabbed options select “Discover Integrations” and enter “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition” in the “Find” to search.

 

  • Enter “SAP Health Data Services for FHIR” as a product to integrate. You'll get the integration package as shown after this.

 

  • Select the package to view its content. You'll see that it includes one Integration Flow “Replicate Patients from SAP Health Data Services for FHIR to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

Importing Integration Package

There are two ways in which an integration package can be imported and executed.

  • Using the configured workspace of the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Steps are described here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-accelerator-hub/sap-business-accelerator-hub/consume-content?version=Cloud

  • Copying the integration content in the SAP Cloud Integration Suite (Recommended)

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/38a01529209a4dc999ded3b9dd05a552.html

  • Once imported into the Integration Suite, you can see the package in the “Design” tab.

Configurations

  • Setting up cloud connector in SAP BTP for secure communication with SAP Cloud ERP Private.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/de25990e3bfb40c29cdc2a6df49fd63e.html

  • Maintain the message queue
    • Make sure you have the proper role collection assigned to your user in BTP. Refer the link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/799852ea657e400fa07700e976285b14.html
    • Navigate to the BTP dashboard to locate an Event Mesh service instance bound to SAP Health Data Services for FHIR instance.
    • Go to the Event Mesh application.

    • Click on the proper “Message Client” in the Event Mesh dashboard. Client here refers to the Event Mesh service instance which you've created along with SAP Health Data Services for FHIR provisioning.

    • Click on the tab “Queues” and then “Create Queue”.

    • In the subsequent pop-up window, offer your own queue name and click on create. Don't enter values for any other fields. Next for the created queue, click on the “Actions” column as highlighted in blue and select “Queue Subscriptions”.

    • In the subsequent pop-up window, offer the topic as “coredata/Patient”, click on Add and then close the window.

    • This completes the Event Mesh configuration.
  • Security Material in Integration Suite.
    • Go to the Integration Suite subscription application in your sub-account.

  • Click on “Monitor”, next “Integrations and APIs” and then “Security Materials”.

  • Maintain “Security Materials” for the three application and services involved in the integration like following. All the needed information can be retrieved from the service key of the respective services. For each Security Material after filling in the needed inputs, click on Deploy. Ensure that the grant type is as shown. Use the following link to get a detailed description about each field value and configuration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/cd5f25e58497425d9f500f0abbd39363.html#procedure

  • Security Material for Event Mesh.

  • Security Material for SAP Health Data Services for FHIR.

  • Security Material for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

  • This completes the security credential configuration in SAP Integration Suite.

 

  • Configure integration package artifact.
    • Navigate to the iFlow inside the copied integration package.

  • Click on the “Artifacts” tab, select the iFlow and click on Configure.

  • In the next pop-up window, enter the following details for the “Sender”, “Receiver” and “More” tab.
  • Use the following link to get a detailed description about each field value and configuration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/c1e3e07667f6463f9b68f0bd446e1c02.html

  • Enter the following details in the “Receiver” tab.

  • Enter the following details in the “More” tab.

  • Click “Deploy All” to deploy the configuration.

Monitoring

After the above configuration deployment, integration flow status changes to “Started” and can be monitored. Use the following link to monitor the integration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/monitor-integrations

When patient is created in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR, based on the preceding steps, the integration flow will automatically create the corresponding business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Conclusion

With this, I'll like to summarize the blog.

Blog offers you a step-by-step guide to realize integration for the patient data as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Share your experience about the integration package, application, and services used during integration. Are you familiar with the FHIR standard and the resources? If yes, then how do you use within your hospital landscape and for interoperability between systems.

Do let us know through the comments. I'll love to hear your reactions and feedback through comments.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Budget Display in "Monitor Project" App –...
entry.content: I’ve run into the same budget display issue in the Monitor Project app on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. In many cases, it’s caused by missing or incomplete configuration in project control settings or budgeting not being released properly. Make sure the project has an active financial plan and that the relevant WBS elements are assigned correctly. Also check whether the budget profile is activated and if the authorization roles allow budget viewing. A data refresh or cache clear sometimes helps as well. If everything looks right, submitting an SAP support ticket usually gets the issue resolved quickly.

entry.title: Streamlining Expat Ticket Allowances: How SAP Ticket Benefit Solution Meets MENA Workforce Needs
entry.content:
In the MENA region, expatriate employees are often entitled to receive air tickets for themselves and their dependents to travel back to their home countries. For HR and payroll teams, managing these entitlements accurately while staying compliant with local regulations and company policy can be complex. SAP Ticket Benefit solution offers a streamlined and flexible approach to address this challenge.

Overview of SAP Ticket Benefit Solution

The Ticket Benefit solution enables companies to manage ticket entitlements for expat employees and their dependents, whether provided as a monetary allowance or an actual ticket. It supports:

  • Flexible setup aligned with company policy
  • Annual, semi-annual, or custom frequencies
  • Configurable rules for dependents, travel routes, and ticket classes

High-Level Process Steps

Key Features

The solution is built on four core components:

  • Entitlement Recording - Infotype 3408
    The process begins by recording each employee’s entitlement details, such as: 
    • Accrual vs. in-full ticket
    • Frequency of ticket issuance
    • Number of tickets per cycle
    • Travel route and ticket class
    • Number of dependents covered

           These configurations allow organizations to accurately reflect their policies within the system.

  • Calculation - Payroll Function TBCAL
    During payroll runs, the function calculates the ticket balance for each employee and their dependents based on the Infotype records and the Ticket Benefit customizing settings. 

           This ensures entitlement values are updated and reflected in payroll results.

  • Ticket Compensation:
    • Issuing Ticket - Infotype 3409
      For companies that provide actual travel tickets instead of cash allowances, admins can record each ticket issuance directly in Infotype 3409 to keep the system aligned with the tickets provided.
    • Ticket Auto Encashment – Workbench
      The new Ticket Benefit Workbench further streamlines ticket allowance processing by identifying employees and dependents who have reached the end of their ticket cycle. It enables bulk creation of compensation records, reducing manual effort while improving process consistency and transparency. For implementation details, please refer to SAP Note 3680164.
  • Correction - Infotype 3410
    When adjustments are required, Infotype 3410 allows admins to specify who the correction applies to and add or deduct the appropriate number of tickets. This ensures ticket balances remain accurate and up to date.

Conclusion

The SAP Ticket Benefit solution is more than a compliance enabler. By leveraging this solution, organizations can:

  • Improve operational efficiency through automation and bulk processing
  • Maintain accurate entitlement records
  • Enhance employee satisfaction

For detailed documentation and configuration guidance, refer to the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
In H2 2026 the username and password authentication process for onboarding will be deprecated and they will need to use IAS to log in.  In this article we will discuss various options to consider when implementing IAS for onboarding.  We will assume that IAS is already enabled for Employee Central.

Implementing IAS is quite simple for an onboarding perspective, a switch is enabled in provisioning and emails need to be adjusted.  All the logic in IAS should be built by an IAS consultant.

Emails

When IAS is enabled for onboarding the ‘username/password’ is sent from IAS rather than from SuccessFactors.  I prefer to still send the ‘External Welcome email’ from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  The welcome email explains that they will get a second email with the login credentials.  I prefer to send two emails as we can customize this email to a greater extent than the IAS email.  In the welcome email you will need to remove the password reset and username, and this will need to be removed for the rehire email as well.  The login link in the other emails will work with IAS.

To get two emails to be sent at the same time will require the real time synch in IAS.

The first email comes from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  This is the external email welcome template. 

The second email comes at the same time from IAS and will allow them to set their password to log in.

To log on they click on the link, and they set their password.

Once they have reset their password they should be redirect to the login page; to do this you will need to set up the redirect in IAS.

Once they have submitted their username and password you can choose to add a new layer of authentication.  Once way is to send a code to their email address.  You can also send this by SMS but this will require a third party provider.

Once they submit the code they will be able to log in.

Once they log in, they can proceed with onboarding as normal.

On their hire date the individual will not get a new IAS account but will be moved to an employee group and they will be able to log in with same IAS account. 

Rehires

When an employee is terminated from Employee Central then their details are typically deleted from IAS, they can be made inactivated, but it is advised that they are deleted.  ips.delete.existedbefore.entities=true

When onboarding starts the onboardee receives an email as above.  When the rehire, check has been completed it follows the same process as without IAS, they get an new IAS email to go in that is linked to their inactive Employee Central Account.  As the old IAS account was deleted this is new IAS account but liked to the inactive user record.  Once they log in their can proceed with onboarding as normal.

When deploying IAS, it is imperative that the rehire process is fully tested.

Implementing IAS whilst live with Onboarding.

Some onboardees  will be using the old username and password method.  As you approach the deployment, we suggest the following.

  • About 2-3 weeks before go live update the welcome email so users know you are changing the authentication process, and they will get a new email to log in. 
  • Add this to a custom homepage tile, this is just there to prevent any concerns over phishing.
  • On go live day pause all initiation of onboarding
  • Update onboarding IAS email with text applicable to all onboardee who are currently in the process, explaining what they need to do.
  • Synch onboarding with IAS, once this is completed update onboarding IAS email with standard text
  • Restart onboarding initiation
